{"error":"OK","limit":2,"offset":0,"number_of_page_results":2,"number_of_total_results":8009,"status_code":1,"results":[{"aliases":"Mid-air Jump","api_detail_url":"http:\/\/www.giantbomb.com\/api\/concept\/3015-1\/","date_added":"2008-05-06 17:47:32","date_last_updated":"2015-02-22 02:17:42","deck":"A double jump is the ability to jump while already in mid-air to get some extra lift. In reality, double jumps are not possible and violate fundamental laws of physics.","description":"

Overview<\/h2>

Double jumping is a commonly used game mechanic where the character can jump once, then in the air jump again. Though it is most commonly used in platform games, double jumping can also be seen in action games. Fighting games and third-person shooter games have also used double jumps, but far more rarely.<\/p>

Games with Double Jump<\/h2>

Dragon Buster<\/b><\/a><\/h3>

Supposedly the first game to feature a Double Jump, it was released in 1984.<\/p>

Legacy of the Wizard<\/a><\/h3>

This game had a cheat<\/a> that let the player perform a second jump from mid-air.<\/p>

Team Fortress 2<\/a><\/b><\/h3>

The Scout<\/a> in Team Fortress is the only class capable of Double Jumping, as befits his speed and agility.<\/p>

Devil May Cry<\/a><\/b><\/h3>

The protagonists of the devil may Cry series have had Double Jump in them; in this game though it is called the Air Hike. When used, the character seems to create a magical platform below his feet from which he can jump again.<\/p>

Super Smash Bros.<\/a><\/b><\/h3>

Nearly every character in the series is capable of performing a Double Jump, even players that in their own games are unable to do so. Characters unable to Double Jump have flight as a substitute.<\/p>

Castlevania Symphony of the Night<\/a><\/b><\/h3>

In this installment of the Castlevania franchise, the player could obtain an item called a Leap Stone that allowed him to Double Jump. Instead of performing an actual second jump though, Alucard's cape turns into wings and boosting him up. Since then, nearly every Castlevania game has an item that allows the player character to double jump.<\/p>

Psychonauts<\/a><\/b><\/h3>

Protagonist Raz<\/a> can use his psychic abilities to jump on a bubble of psychic energy granting a double jump.<\/p>

Sonic 3 and Knuckles<\/b><\/a><\/h3>

Sonic<\/a> cannot normally double jump, the electric shield power-up grants him the ability. While Tails<\/a> and Knuckles<\/a> can also collect the shield, they can not use it to double jump.<\/p>

Crash Bandicoot: Warped<\/b><\/a><\/h3>

Crash<\/a> unlocks double jump after beating the second boss Dingodile.<\/p>

Unreal Tournament<\/a><\/strong><\/h3>

Double jumping debuted in UT 2003<\/a> and UT 2004<\/a> and allowed players to do trick jumps and help players in avoiding projectiles and disturbing the other players, it also helped in reaching areas impossible to reach with a single jump. There is a mutator which allows players to quad jump and this allowed the player to jump at similar heights as we could do in the previous unreal games with the jump boots.<\/p>

The third game in the Unreal Tournament franchise, UT3<\/a>, also featured a double jump.<\/p>","first_appeared_in_franchise":{"api_detail_url":"http:\/\/www.giantbomb.com\/api\/franchise\/3025-2530\/","id":2530,"name":"Dragon Buster"},"first_appeared_in_game":{"api_detail_url":"http:\/\/www.giantbomb.com\/api\/game\/3030-12337\/","id":12337,"name":"Dragon Buster"},"id":1,"image":{"icon_url":"http:\/\/www.giantbomb.com\/api\/image\/square_avatar\/9740-scout.jpg","medium_url":"http:\/\/www.giantbomb.com\/api\/image\/scale_medium\/9740-scout.jpg","screen_url":"http:\/\/www.giantbomb.com\/api\/image\/screen_medium\/9740-scout.jpg","small_url":"http:\/\/www.giantbomb.com\/api\/image\/scale_small\/9740-scout.jpg","super_url":"http:\/\/www.giantbomb.com\/api\/image\/scale_large\/9740-scout.jpg","thumb_url":"http:\/\/www.giantbomb.com\/api\/image\/scale_avatar\/9740-scout.jpg","tiny_url":"http:\/\/www.giantbomb.com\/api\/image\/square_mini\/9740-scout.jpg"},"name":"Double Jump","site_detail_url":"http:\/\/www.giantbomb.com\/double-jump\/3015-1\/"},{"aliases":null,"api_detail_url":"http:\/\/www.giantbomb.com\/api\/concept\/3015-2\/","date_added":"2008-05-13 15:47:17","date_last_updated":"2016-05-19 23:58:46","deck":"An Easter Egg is an intentionally hidden cheat or hidden content in a video game, also known as a \"secret\".","description":"

Overview<\/h2>

Easter Eggs can be hidden treats, homages<\/a>, trivia<\/a>, or anything developers wish to hide, with the intention of being found, within a game. The placement of an Easter Egg is typically such that they usually take some hunting to find, hence the name.<\/p>

Examples<\/h2>

Easter Eggs have appeared in games for literally decades. Developers simply can't help but put in references to their favorite things and people, including themselves.<\/p>

Adventure<\/a> - 1979 - Atari 2600<\/a><\/h3>

At the time of Adventure's release, Atari was not in the practice of crediting its developers with the work they produced. Thus, Warren Robinett, the developer of Adventure, did it himself by hiding his name and title within the game for players to find. This serves as one of the first known Easter Eggs in gaming.<\/p>

Battlezone<\/a> - 1998 - PC<\/a><\/h3>

Hidden within the very first level of the game was the Rave Gun<\/a>, a weapon which fired balls of powerful energy in bursts of color which flashed across the screen in time to a pounding trance techno beat.<\/p>

Doom II: Hell on Earth - 1994 - PC<\/h3>

Doom II: Hell on Earth<\/a> actually contained several Easter eggs, including the severed head of Producer\/Programmer\/Level Designer John Romero<\/a> on a stick. Oddly enough, the head also functioned as the final boss' \"weak point\" in the game. Additionally, the player could access two extra levels not included in the normal level progression of the game. These levels were recreations of two levels from id Software's famous Wolfenstein 3-D<\/a>, and to beat the second level, players had to murder four representations of Commander Keen<\/a>.<\/p>

Fallout<\/a> - 1997 - PC<\/h3>

Among the many Easter eggs players with high luck stats can stumble across while wandering between the game's areas are, a large Godzilla-like foot print with a corpse inside, a used car dealership and a crashed U.F.O containing a ray gun and a photo of Elvis.<\/p>

Grand Theft Auto IV<\/a> - 2008 - Xbox 360<\/a>, PS3<\/a>, PC<\/h3>

One of several Easter eggs found within Grand Theft Auto IV<\/a> is within the Statue of Happiness (Liberty City<\/a>'s version of the Statue of Liberty<\/a>), where the player can find a huge beating heart, dubbed the \"Heart of the City\".<\/p>

Grand Theft Auto: Vice City<\/a> - 2002 PC, PS2<\/a>, Xbox<\/a><\/h3>
